name: Soundicvision SD-200
keyboard: One controller with 4 directions joystick mounted on a disk, 2 fire buttons (same function) and a knob for breakout-type games
ports: Two controller connectors, cartidge slot, power in, RF TV output
description:
The Soundic SD-200 is a low-range console with rather simplistic games. It was released around 1983. It is one of these cheap systems produced in Asia for people not able to buy more expensive systems of that time.

The Soundicvision is exactly the same system as the Hanimex HMG-7900, and though different in shape, is internaly the same system as the Rollet Video-Color and the ITMC SD-290.

There were surely all produced by Soundic in Hong-Kong as all the systems have code-names like "SD-2xx" (where SD would mean Soundic) on their electronic boards. Hanimex HMG-7900 and Soundicvision are SD-200 systems, the Rollet Videocolor's electronic board is labeled SD-270, and the ITMC was marketed under the SD-290 name. Soundic thus produced cheap systems and sold them to foreign companies used to market these systems like Hanimex, ITMC, Rollet, etc. They also sometimes sold their systems under their own brand, as seen here with the Soundic Soundicvision SD-200 in Finland.

Read Hanimex HMG-7900 entry for more info.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> LEFT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here is the player-1 controller connector.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pelikonepeijoonit.net/" target="_blank">Pelikonepeijoonit</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> RIGHT SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Here is the second player joystick connector, which is never used...<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://pelikonepeijoonit.net/" target="_blank">Pelikonepeijoonit</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (NOV.1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"don't touch my Amstrad gaming system !"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken </b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.primo.homeserver.hu/" target="_blank">PRIMO home-page</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FLYER</strong></font><br><blockquote>... featuring the Intellivoice</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1979 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC.1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Evolutiv system : Casio's answer"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (MAY 1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE ACCESSORIES</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There are more people in more places making more accessories and peripherals for Apples than for any other personal computer in the world.<br> Thanks to those people - in hundreds of independant companies - who can make the humblest 1978 Apple II turn tricks that are still on IBM's Wish List for 1984.<br> But now we're coming out with our very own line of peripherals and accessories for Apple personal computers... </font><br><br> The dual language of Apple: In the same advert, Apple thanks the companies manufacturing Apple compatible peripherals and asks its customers to buy only Apple peripherals in the future....  </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MICRO7 COVERPAGE (SEPT. 84)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Micro7 was a french computing magazine in the 80's. In september 84, its first page was featuring the EXl-100.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #7 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to François Houste and <a href="http://www.phijvmi.com" target="_blank">www.phijvmi.com</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ENGLISH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Intended for educational market.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 84'S PARIS-DAKAR RACE</strong></font><br><blockquote>A KAYPRO IV IN ACTION SOMEWHERE IN AFRICA <br><br> 8 Kaypro IV and 2 Kaypro 10 were used by the doctors of the Paris-Dakar race 84's edition. The Kaypro IVs were used to store medical information about the 1000 participants. Power was provided by the Mercedes cars through the 12v cigarette lighters. The Kaypro 10s were kept in the "communication" plane during the day, and were used to centralize all the informations in the evening. At the end of the race, and after 12000 km of tracks, there were all running fine ! One of the Kaypro 10 is said to have been thrown out of the plane, mistaken with a common metallic tool box... And it still worked !</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 1-2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LISA ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>He is rich (enough to buy a LISA !), he is relaxed... He is the typical advertising executive of the 80's.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DICK SMITH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Price list close-up in Australian$:<br> Basic CAT computer X-7500 <b>$1195.00</b><br> Disk Drive X-7505 <b>$1495.00</b><br> Disk Controller X-7510 <b>$149.95</b><br> Emulator Cartridge X-7530 <b>$149.95</b><br> Dual Joysticks X-7520 <b>$49.95</b><br> RF Modulator X-7550 <b>$49.95</b><br> RS-232C Serial Adaptor X-7515 <b>$149.95</b><br> Printer Cable (Centronics) X-7540 <b>$844.95</b><br> Filer Utilities Disk with DOS & Manual X-7512 <b>$59.95</b><br> High resolution RVB monitor X-1193 <b>$995.00</b><br> RGB Cable X-7560 <b>$44.95</b><br> High Res. Green Monitor X-1220 <b>$395.00</b></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> LAST +4 SALES, APR. 1986</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 COLECO CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote>extract from the 1980 Coleco catalog<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.textfiles.com/digitize/items/" target="_blank">Digitize, Textfiles.com</a> for the picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 6000 MODEL</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> WE HAVE A NEW APPROACH TO DISTRIBUTED PROCESSING THAT WORKS <br><br> Already implemented are electronic mail, word processing, complete cost accounting with inventory control and more. The secret is a new technology called Functionally Structured Distribution (FSD). At last, a system to organize and manage distributed processing applications that is really up and running. FSD technology is especially applicable to installa­tions that require:<br> • Unlimited expandability supporting extremely large data bases and terminals in many cities.<br> • User-friendly software easily programmed in high level languages (COBOL, FORTRAN, and BASIC)<br> • System reliability (due to distributed hardware) while maintaining multiple levels of data security.<br> • Compatibility with existing mainframes and networks (including the Bell System). <br><br> We are presently installing Billings 6000 Computer Systems which take full advantage of distributed processing utilizing FSD technology. The 6000 Computer supports multiple hard disk drives with capacities of up to 64 Mbytes (formatted), streaming tapes for backup, auto-dial modems (2400 baud synchronous) for communications, and flexible disk drives for smaller installations.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JULY 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Page 2 <br><br> "The domestic computer, business class"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. ADVERT (1990)</strong></font><br><blockquote>In this U.K. advert, the Amiga 1500 was sold at £1149.99 with a colour monitor, 4 games (Battle Chess, Sim City, Populous, Battle of Britain) and the home business suite Platinium Works. <br><br> The Amiga 500 was also sold at £399.99<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pelikonepeijoonit.net">The Arctic Computer & Console Museum</a></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
